headline.main: THE PUBLIC HEALTH.; Medical Men to Manage Medical Matters in the City Government.

docs.lead_paragraph: It is generally conceded that a tailor makes a better fitting coat than a blacksmith can; that an architect is more competent to draft a plan for a sew church than is a hostler; and in private late it is customary to employ to do a special job a man whose tastes and training have fitted his specially for that sort of work.

docs.snippet: A good anecdote of Professor Agassiz is told in a new volume in Press at Boston. The Professor had declined to deliver a lecture before some lyceum, or public society, on account of the inroads which previous lectures given by him had made upon his...
docs.lead_paragraph: A good anecdote of Professor Agassiz is told in a new volume in Press at Boston. The Professor had declined to deliver a lecture before some lyceum, or public society, on account of the inroads which previous lectures given by him had made upon his studies and habits of thought.

docs.lead_paragraph: GENERAL APPEARARANCE OF THE CITY. CLOSING OF STORES, BANKS AND PUBLIC OFFICERS-MILITARY PARADES .AC. The weather, yesterday, was cold and the sky overcast. Most of the stores on Broadway were closed, but in the avenues and minor streets the holiday was not strictly kept, and Gubertorial proclannations were, by many, milterly disregurdal.

docs.snippet: SENATE SANITARY COMMITTEE.--Mr. A. J. H. DUGANNE appeared before the Senate Committee yesterday afternoon, and read a statement with reference to the Teaement-houses of the City. He argued that regulations are necessary for the public health:...
docs.lead_paragraph: SENATE SANITARY COMMITTEE.--Mr. A. J. H. DUGANNE appeared before the Senate Committee yesterday afternoon, and read a statement with reference to the Teaement-houses of the City. He argued that regulations are necessary for the public health: Firstly, with regard to ever-population of certain districts and certain houses.

docs.snippet: In the Circuit Court at Batavia, before Judge Davis, Barber G. Buell recovered $4,450 in a suit against the Central Railroad Company, in consequence of injuries received on the cars at Bergen, in October, 1897. The Ch?? Advocate and Journal says: "A...
docs.lead_paragraph: In the Circuit Court at Batavia, before Judge Davis, Barber G. Buell recovered $4,450 in a suit against the Central Railroad Company, in consequence of injuries received on the cars at Bergen, in October, 1897. The Ch?? Advocate and Journal says: "A young man came up. immediately after it was known that we had increased (by $30,000) the missionary impropriation for the year, and said he would give $1,000 the coming year."

docs.snippet: BY JOHN A. KING, GOVERNOR OF THE STATE OF NEW-YORK. Another year of abundant harvests, of general health, contentment, and tranquillity, admonishes us of our first and constant duty, to render thanks and praise to Him who is the gracious Author and...
docs.lead_paragraph: BY JOHN A. KING, GOVERNOR OF THE STATE OF NEW-YORK. Another year of abundant harvests, of general health, contentment, and tranquillity, admonishes us of our first and constant duty, to render thanks and praise to Him who is the gracious Author and Giver of those needful benefits, and the manifold blessings we have been permitted to enjoy;

docs.lead_paragraph: A "SPIRITUAL" DOCTOR IN TROUBLE.--The town of Franklin, N. H., has been considerably agitated for some days past, in consequence of the doings of a mesmerie or spiritual physician, calling himself Dr. L. D. PIKE, It appears that Dr. PIKE entered the town several weeks since, announcing himself as being peculiarly gifted in curing all diseases,

docs.snippet: We left Simoda ou the 5th inst., bound to this place, via Nagasaki, with the Treaty. The second day out we encountered quite a severe gale, which handled even us quite roughly, and caused us to wish all smaller vessels safety under shelter. Entering...
docs.lead_paragraph: We left Simoda ou the 5th inst., bound to this place, via Nagasaki, with the Treaty. The second day out we encountered quite a severe gale, which handled even us quite roughly, and caused us to wish all smaller vessels safety under shelter. Entering Nagasaki, after a passage of six days, we noticed the wreck of a European vessel at the mouth of the labor, evidently a victim of the late typhoon.

docs.lead_paragraph: A correspondent of the New-Orleans ?? writes from Minatitlan, Nov. 3, as follows: "Having taken on board the passengers and mails brought by the Quaker City, the Suchil left the steamship on Saturday, 30th ult., at 1 P.M., and proceeded on her pioneer trip. We were greeted with the most enthusias?? cancers by the inhabitants as we passed up the river, and our whole party was in the finest spirits.

headline.main: ILLINOIS.; Illness of the Hon. J.L. Harris--Alleged Illegality of Republican Votes in Chicago.

docs.lead_paragraph: I have just returned from the bedside of the Hon. JAMES L. HARRIS ; probably the next letter you will receive must announce his death. You remember that during the last session of Congress he was scarcely able to perform the duties of his position on account of ill-health. He returned home and partially recovered, but was again prostrated by the accidental use of a poisonous drug.
